subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: get your news in QS!
msgSnippet: Excellent work, Paul! I think I sense a new open-source project team taking shape here. Are you willing to contribute your code, Paul? In addition to the ideas
messageBody:
Excellent work, Paul!

I think I sense a new open-source project team taking shape here. Are
you willing to contribute your code, Paul? In addition to the ideas
already offered, I'd like to see settings for at least two different
accents: General American and RP (if that is not adequate, then
several choices to represent accents of the British Isles). For more
discrimating users, there should be a detailed settings page where the
user can choose the QS letter corresponding to each lexical set. This
page would look very similar to the figures Anthony put together with
gray and black words for the lexical sets.

As has already been pointed out, code development is the minor part of
the work for such a project. The main effort would require a team of
database curators with at least one person taking the lead for each
major accent. It should be stressed that these people need not be
software developers.

The CMU Dictionary provides an excellent starting point for General
American. Is there a similarly available resource for RP?

Ted


On Nov 11, 2007 6:01 AM, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
> >I have seemed to work out a way to download the top stores, convert
> >these stories to Quikscript, and post them on my site.
>
> So cool! I so wish I'd thought of that!
>
>
> >That's where the real heart of this whole process lies--in the
> dictionary. I
> >was lucky that there is a word data base of 100 000 words, that lists
> >words with suffixes and prefixes. So a portion looks like this:
>
> If you are using the CMU dictionary, the entries include stress marks
> next to the phonetics (a number 0, 1 or 2). In particular 0 means no
> stress. If you felt like it, this could be used to approximate the
> rules for terminal unstressed "y" "al" "el" "le" "ier" "ey "ie" etc if
> desired (things explicitly needed in senior anyway). Of course such
> refinements are insignificant compared with the idea and
> implementation of the live-ish QS conversion in the first place.
>
>
> > How is a program to know if "bush" means the shrub or the president?
> In the
> > future I hope the program may get a bit more sophisticated to handle
> > these situations.
>
> Not that I've tried it, but to approximate this, maybe any capital
> letter not preceded but terminal punctuation (period, question mark
> etc) and not starting a block of text can be assumed to be a name.
>
>
>
